ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.2_0: At that time a man who was going away said to his wife, “Weigh some thread, take it to the weavers, have them weave robe-cloth, and put the robe-cloth aside.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.3_0: When I return I’ll give it to Venerable Upananda.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.4_0: An alms-collecting monk heard that man making that statement.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.5_0: Then that monk went to Upananda,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.5_1: and after approaching he said this to Upananda: “Upananda, you have much merit.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.6_0: In such-and-such a place I heard that a man was going to such-and-such a monastery and said to him, “I’ll give you a robe,” and then put it aside with the robe-cloth as his weak.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.8_0: And the weaver was Upananda’s supporter too.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.9_0: Just then Upananda went to that monastery.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.10_0: “This robe-cloth that you’re weaving for me.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.10_2: And make it closely woven, well-woven, well-stretched, well-scraped, and well-combed.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.11_0: “Venerable, they’ve already weighed the thread and given it to me, saying,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.13_0: I won’t be able to make it long, wide, or closely woven.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.14_0: But I’m able to make it well-woven, well-stretched, well-scraped, and well-combed.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.15_0: “Just make it long, wide, and closely woven.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.16_0: There won’t be any lack of thread.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.17_1: and after approaching he said, “Venerable, you need borrowed her.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.18_0: “But didn’t I tell you to weave the robe-cloth with that thread?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.20_0: But Venerable Upananda told me to make it long, wide, and closely woven.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.21_0: And he said there wouldn’t be any lack of thread.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.22_0: That woman then gave him as much thread again as she had done the first time.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.23_0: Upananda heard that man had returned from his travels.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.23_1: Just then Upananda went to that person’s house.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.23_2: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.24_1: and after approaching and worshipping the Sakyan sat down on one side.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.25_0: He then said to his wife, “Has the robe-cloth been woven?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.27_0: “Please bring it, I’ll give it to Venerable Upananda.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.28_0: She then got the robe-cloth, gave it to her husband, and told him what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.29_0: After giving the robe-cloth to Upananda, he complained and criticized him,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.30_0: “These Sakyan ascetics have great desires; they are not content.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.31_0: It’s no easy matter to give them robe-cloth.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.32_0: How could Venerable Upananda go to the weavers and specify the kind of robe-cloth he wanted without first being invited by me?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.33_0: The monks heard the complaints of that person,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.34_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.35_0: “How can Venerable Upananda go to a householder’s weavers and specify the kind of robe-cloth he wants without first being invited?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.36_0: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.37_0: “Is it true, Upananda, that you acted like this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.41_0: “Foolish man, people who are not related don’t know what’s appropriate and what’s inappropriate in dealing with each other, what’s right and what’s wrong.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.42_0: And still you went to the weavers of an unrelated householder and specified the kind of robe-cloth you wanted without first being invited.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.43_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.44_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.45.1_0: ‘If a male or female householder has set aside a robe-cloth for an unrelated monk—a householder or a monk—when they want to previously inact the kind of robe-cloth he wants, without first being invited—that is to go to him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.46_0: ‘This robe-cloth that you’re weaving for me.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.46_2: make it closely woven, well-woven, well-stretched, well-scraped, and well-combed;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.47_0: and perhaps I will even give you a small gift;’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.48_0: If he stays in that way, even if only almsfood, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.2_0: for the benefit of a monk; making a monk the object of consideration, one desires to give to him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.4_0: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back seven generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.8_0: any woman who lives at home.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.12_0: one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, but not smaller than what can be transferred to another.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.16_0: the monk for whom the robe-cloth is being woven.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.18_0: without it first being said, “Venerable, what kind of robe-cloth do you need? What kind of robe-cloth should I get woven for you?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.20_0: having gone to their house or having gone wherever.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.21_0: Specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.22_0: “This robe-cloth that you’re weaving for me, make it long and wide.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.23_0: make it closely woven, well-woven, well-stretched, well-scraped, and well-combed;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.24_0: and perhaps I will even give you a small gift.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.25_0: Then in saying that and afterwards giving them a small gift, even if it is only a bit of almsfood—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.27_0: rice porridge, a meal, non-staple food, a bit of bath powder, a toothbrush, a piece of string, and even if he gives a teaching.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.28_0: If the weaver makes it long or wide or closely woven because of the monk’s statement, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.29_0: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.30_0: The blanket should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.31_0: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this. ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.33_0: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth for which I went to the weavers of an unrelated householder and specified the kind of robe-cloth I wanted without first being invited is to be relinquished.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.34_0: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.37_0: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.38.1_0: If the householder is unrelated and the monk perceives them as such and, without first being invited, he approaches the lay person’s weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.39_0: If the householder is unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it and, without first being invited, he approaches the lay person’s weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.40_0: If the householder is unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related and, without first being invited, he approaches the lay person’s weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.41_0: If the lay person is related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.42_0: If the person is related, but the monk is unsure of it, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.43_0: If the person is related and the monk perceives them as such, there is no offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.44.1_0: there is no offense for him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.47_0: if it is built for someone else;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.48_0: if it is by means of her own property;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.49_0: if someone wants to have expensive robe-cloth woven, but he has them weave inexpensive robe-cloth instead;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.51_0: if he is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.52_0: The seventh rule, the training rule on large dwellings, is finished.
